title: Tom Cotton
added: On September 2020, Trump named Cotton as a potential Supreme Court nominee.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Klar|first=Rebecca|date=2020-09-09|title=Tom Cotton after Trump names him potential Supreme Court nominee: 'It's time for Roe v. Wade to go'|url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/515728-tom-cotton-after-trump-names-him-possible-justice-its-time-for-roe-v|work=TheHill|date=September 10, 2020|access-date=September 11, 2020}}</ref>

title: Tom Cotton
deleted: In August 2013, Cotton voted against the [[Bipartisan Student Loan Certainty Act of 2013]], that sets interest rates on student loans to the 10-year Treasury note plus a varying mark up for undergraduate and graduate students. Cotton preferred a solution that ended what he described as the "...federal-government monopoly on the student-lending business." His characterization referred to the provision of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] that changed the way the federal government makes student loans.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Robertson |first1=Lori |title=Student Loan Stretching |url=https://www.factcheck.org/2014/10/student-loan-stretching/ |website=FactCheck.org |accessdate=17 April 2020}}</ref>

title: Tom Cotton
added: In August 2013, Cotton voted against the [[Bipartisan Student Loan Certainty Act of 2013]], that sets interest rates on student loans to the 10-year Treasury note plus a varying mark up for undergraduate and graduate students. Cotton preferred a solution that ended what he described as the "...federal-government monopoly on the student-lending business." His characterization referred to the provision of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] that changed the way the federal government makes student loans.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Robertson |first1=Lori |title=Student Loan Stretching |url=https://www.factcheck.org/2014/10/student-loan-stretching/ |website=FactCheck.org |accessdate=17 April 2020}}</ref>

title: Tom Cotton
deleted: In October 2006, ''The New York Times'' [[public editor]] [[Byron Calame]] reversed his previous position that supported the article, saying that the paper should not have published the story, though he said the decision "was a close call now, as it was then."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/22/opinion/22pubed.html?pagewanted=2 | work= The New York Times | title=Can 'Magazines' of The Times Subsidize News Coverage? | first=Byron | last=Calame | date=October 22, 2006 | accessdate=May 25, 2010}}</ref>
